thread.title: Latest Maine, New Hampshire and Vermont news, sports, business and entertainment
thread.title_full: Latest Maine, New Hampshire and Vermont news, sports, business and entertainment - WCAX.COM Local Vermont News, Weather and Sports-

author: wcax.com
title: Latest Maine, New Hampshire and Vermont news, sports, business and entertainment
text:
MAINE:
SPRINGFIELD, Mass. (AP) - Maine Governor Paul LePage is in Massachusetts to take part in "Maine Day" festivities at the 2015 Eastern States Exposition. The Maine Department of Agriculture, Conservation and Forestry oversees the state's participation in the annual event, which is the biggest agricultural expo in New England.
ROCKLAND, Maine (AP) - Officials say a 78-year-old lobsterman was found dead on his boat after the Coast Guard and Maine Marine Patrol responded to a runaway lobster boat in Rockland. A ferry operator spotted the boat going in circles near Owls Head State Park on Friday afternoon with an unresponsive person lying on the deck of the vessel. A Coast Guard member tried to revive Robert Staples of North Haven but was unsuccessful.
AUGUSTA, Maine (AP) - The Maine moose hunt's first session is ending today. The next session starts on Oct. 12, ends Oct. 17 and covers much more of the state. The second moose hunting session allows hunters to pursue moose in much of northern and parts of central Maine. The first session was limited to far northern and northeastern Maine. There will be another session in November.
AUGUSTA, Maine (AP) - The chairwoman of Maine's Unemployment Insurance Commission has reversed a decision to award unemployment benefits to workers who went on strike against FairPoint Communications. Two unions reacted angrily yesterday to the decision by Chairwoman Jennifer Duddy, an appointee of Republican Gov. Paul LePage, to overturn an earlier finding by a hearing officer made in June.
NEW HAMPSHIRE:
HOOKSETT, N.H. (AP) - Republican White House hopefuls Ted Cruz, Rick Santorum and Carly Fiorina are appearing at a New Hampshire forum on limiting the powers of the federal government. The American Principles Project is hosting the forum today in Hooksett.
GOFFSTOWN, N.H. (AP) - Three days after a gunman opened fire at a community college in Oregon, New Hampshire authorities are conducting an emergency drill to test responses in a possible similar situation. Tomorrow's drill was scheduled well before Thursday's shooting at Umpqua Community College in Oregon, where nine people were killed and seven others wounded.
CONCORD, N.H. (AP) - The New Hampshire Fish and Game Department is giving a free talk on deer hunting basics. Whitetail deer are New Hampshire's most sought-after game animal. Last year, hunters took 11,395 deer in the state. The talk by hunter education instructor Dave Priebe is scheduled for Wednesday at 7 p.m. at department headquarters in Concord.
CONCORD, N.H. (AP) - Two rail carriers are asking a federal judge to find them exempt from state and local regulations regarding their proposal to unload propane. Boston and Maine Corp. and Springfield Terminal Railway Co., subsidiaries of Pan Am Railways, filed a complaint on Wednesday in federal court in Concord against the city of Portsmouth and City Manager John Bohenko.
VERMONT:
MONTPELIER, Vt. (AP) - The Vermont Department of Public Service is seeking public opinion on a draft of the state's comprehensive energy plan. A public hearing is scheduled for Wednesday in Lyndonville. The Lyndonville meeting is one of five public hearings that will be held across the state in October.
GEORGIA, Vt. (AP) - Vermont's Georgia Mountain Community Wind project is offering tours of its wind turbines. The tours are planned for this afternoon from 1 p.m. to 4 p.m. at the wind farm. Last year more than 600 people visited the site during the tours.
BURLINGTON, Vt. (AP) - There's a new statewide phone line that can be used by people seeking to support Vermont families with young children. Parents and caregivers may now dial 2-1-1 to be connected with trained development specialists at the Help Me Grow program. The experts will be able to answer questions about children's behavior and development and help connect the families to resources and services in their community.
BURLINGTON, Vt. (AP) - The University of Vermont has received a $20 million donation - its largest individual gift ever - and renamed its business school after the donor. UVM announced the gift on Friday from Steven Grossman, a 1961 graduate. The school will be called The Grossman School of Business. UVM says the donation from the Grossman Family Foundation will pay for three endowed academic positions. The school says the gift will also provide resources to support teaching and program priorities.
